metadata./Title: Post-traumatic cerebral venous sinus thrombosis complicated with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion: a case report

sections.Background:
Background Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis is a rare but potentially life-threatening condition resulting 
from the formation of a thrombus in the venous sinuses in the brain, resulting in impaired venous drainage, increased 
intracranial pressure, and severe neurological deficits. Traumatic cerebral venous sinus thrombosis is a rare but potentially devastating complication of head trauma. Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis can present with a variety of symp toms including headache, vomiting, blurred vision, loss of consciousness, seizures, and coma. Syndrome of inappro priate antidiuretic hormone secretion is a complication of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis that occurs due to raised 
intracranial pressure, which in turn stimulates antidiuretic hormone release. The diagnosis of cerebral venous sinus 
thrombosis is confirmed through neuroimaging. Anticoagulation remains the mainstay of treatment. The prognosis 
is variable and depends on several factors including the extent of thrombosis, presence of cerebral hemorrhage, 
and timing of diagnosis and treatment.
sections.Case Presentation:
Case presentation We report a case of a 45-year-old Albanian female who presented with headache and dizziness 
following a fall and head strike in the context of influenza A. Computed tomography of the brain revealed a stable 
minimally displaced oblique fracture of the left petrous bone and new dural venous sinus thrombosis of the left transverse sinus, left sigmoid sinus, and cranial aspect of the left internal jugular vein. Thrombotic, malignancy, and infectious screens were negative. Our case was successfully managed with anticoagulants. Additionally, the patient developed syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion, which was managed with fluid restriction.
sections.Conclusion:
Conclusion Our case highlights the importance of considering cerebral venous sinus thrombosis as a differential 
diagnosis in patients presenting with dizziness following trauma. Early identification with computed tomography 
or magnetic resonance imaging venography and appropriate treatment with anticoagulation therapy are essential 
to reduce morbidity and mortality.

Background
Cerebral venous thrombosis includes thrombosis of the 
cerebral venous sinus, deep cerebral veins, cortical veins, 
and dural venous sinus [1]. The causes of CVST can be 
categorized as hypercoagulable conditions (primary 
and secondary) that are surgical and post-traumatic. Open Access

Trauma-related CVST can be categorized as intrinsic and 
extrinsic. Intrinsic factors include fractures that extend 
into the dura and venous sinuses, direct trauma to the 
venous sinus, intimal injury, and fractures that compress 
the venous sinuses itself. Extrinsic compression refers to 
external force exerted by traumatized nearby structures 
[1]. CVST can present with symptoms similar to other 
neurological disorders such as migraine, brain tumors, 
and intracranial hemorrhage [1]. The management of 
CSVT requires a comprehensive diagnostic assessment to 
determine the underlying etiological causes, followed by 
appropriate treatment [2]. Anticoagulant therapy is indi cated in patients with CVST to prevent clot expansion 
and to promote clot resolution. Intracranial hemorrhage 
is not considered a contraindication for anticoagulants in 
CVST. Symptomatic treatment involves the management 
of seizures and increased intracranial pressure, which 
could lead to vision loss and headache [2].
Case presentation
A 45-year-old previously healthy Albanian female pre sented with headache, dizziness, and a fall with a head 
strike in the context of influenza A, which had been pre sent for 10  days. On examination, her Glasgow Coma 
Scale score was 15/15. She was hemodynamically sta ble. Saturation on air was 99%, and her respiratory rate 
was 18 breaths per minute. Her lungs were clear, and 
her abdomen was soft and non-tender. Upper limbs and 
lower limbs were neurologically normal. Cranial nerve 
examination was unremarkable.
Initial computed tomography (CT) brain angiogram 
revealed a focal hemorrhagic contusion of the medial 
right frontal lobe, stable extradural hematoma, stable 
minimally displaced oblique fracture of the left petrous 
bone, and new dural venous sinus thrombosis of the left 
transverse sinus, left sigmoid sinus, and cranial aspect of 
the left internal jugular vein. MRI of the brain confirmed 
this (Fig. 1).
Initial blood investigations, including full blood count, 
renal functions, liver functions, and inflammatory mark ers, were normal. The case was discussed with the hema tology and neurosurgical teams, and she was started on 
therapeutic clexane.
On day 3 following admission, her sodium dropped 
to 128 mmol/L. Serum osmolality was 271  mOsm/
kg, urine osmolality was 522  mOsm/kg, and urinary 
sodium was 131  mmol/L. She was reviewed by the 
endocrine team, who advised treatment as for SIADH 
secondary to traumatic brain injury, with fluid restric tion. Left temporal bone fracture was assessed by the 
ear, nose, and throat (ENT) specialists. Ciprofloxacin 
ear drops and oral steroids were prescribed, and the plan was to follow up in 1 week at ENT clinic. Throm bophilia screen including a antiphospholipid screen, 
protein C, protein S, antithrombin III, and homocyst eine was negative. Autoimmune screen, malignancy 
screen, and infectious screen were negative. Hence, the 
diagnosis was traumatic venous sinus thrombosis.
Over the next few days her symptoms gradually 
improved. Her sodium level normalized. As per hema tology’s advice, a repeat MRI of the brain was con ducted after 1 week of admission. This revealed right 
frontal lobe changes representing a focal cortical con tusion and small left temporal and resolving right fron tal subdural hematomas without associated mass effect 
and resolving venous sinus thrombosis. These findings 
were discussed with the neurosurgery and hematology 
teams, following which she was started on apixaban 
5 mg twice daily. The patient was educated on the side 
effects of apixaban, and the plan was to continue apixa ban 5 mg twice daily for 3 months. She was discharged, 
and general medical and hematology clinic follow-up 
was arranged. At 3  months following discharge, on 
review at the medical clinic the patient was asympto matic and did not have bleeding or other side effects of 
apixaban. Repeat MRI of the brain revealed the resolu tion of CVST, and apixaban was ceased.

sections.Discussion:
Discussion
Cerebral venous sinus thrombosis is a rare condition 
characterized by blood clotting in the cerebral venous or 
dural sinuses and in extreme circumstances, the cortical 
veins [3]. It is an uncommon but possibly lethal cause of 
sudden decline in neurological function that was previ ously linked to cutaneous infections of the orbit, central 
face, and otomastoid. After antibiotics became available, 
the most prevalent causes were neoplasms, pregnancy, 
puerperium, systemic disorders, dehydration, intracra nial tumors, oral contraceptives, and coagulopathies. 
Surgery, head trauma, arteriovenous malformations, 
infection, paraneoplastic conditions, and autoimmune 
diseases are further factors. However, in 30% of cases, 
there was no underlying cause found [3]. Traumatic 
brain-injury-related CVST is a particular subtype of the 
illness. Unlike spontaneous CVST, it usually
sections.Results:
results from 
a direct mechanical disruption of the vascular wall. As in 
our case, known risk factors for its development include 
fractures and epidural hematomas covering a dural 
venous sinus [4].
The signs and symptoms of CVST are diverse and 
might change acutely or gradually over several weeks [5]. 
It is difficult to treat clinically and resembles several neu rological disorders, including stroke, meningitis, enceph alopathy, and benign intracranial hypertension. About 
80% of people with CVST have headaches, which is the 
most common symptom in these patients [6]. Com puted tomographic venography or magnetic resonance 
venography are the main
sections.Methods:
methods used for diagnosis [7]. 
It could be challenging to forecast how cerebral venous 
thrombosis will manifest clinically. Despite receiving 
intense medical care, 10–15% of patients die or become 
dependent. The mainstay of treatment is anticoagulation 
and endovascular therapies [5].
Although cases of cerebral venous sinus thrombosis are 
regularly reported, there are not many cases of traumatic 
venous sinus thrombosis reported in available literature. 
Barbati et al. reported a case of a 15-year-old girl, who 
developed superior sagittal sinus thrombosis following 
closed head injury (pedestrian struck by a vehicle). Due 
to a gradually developing deep coma accompanied by 
high intracranial hypertension, an emergency decom pressive craniectomy was performed. The outcome was 
satisfactory: the patient’s symptoms gradually became 
better, and was able to regain consciousness, had decent 
mobility, and was mentally healthy [7]. Interestingly, 
Chtara et al. published a case series of patients hospital ized in the intensive care unit with post-traumatic cer ebral venous thrombosis. They reported the incidence of 
post-traumatic cerebral venous sinus thrombosis in their 
institution as 4.2%. In this case series five patients had a 
thrombosis in the jugular vein. Seven patients had two or three sites of occlusion. Similar to our patient all patients 
had medical treatment. No hemorrhagic complications 
were reported. They concluded that post-traumatic cer ebral venous sinus thrombosis in the intensive care unit 
is underdiagnosed [8]. In 2022, a case of a 13-year-old 
girl with trauma secondary to a fall from a golf cart was 
reported. She was found to have intraparenchymal and 
subarachnoid hemorrhages with transverse sinus throm bosis. Similar to our case, this patient was treated with 
anti-coagulation, after which she achieved complete res olution [9].
In contrast to above cases with traumatic CVST, our 
case was complicated with SIADH. Several theories are 
proposed for the pathophysiology of SIADH in CVST. 
CVST leads to raised intracranial pressure, which is turn 
stimulates antidiuretic hormone (ADH) release. In addi tion, the brain’s response to disturbed blood flow and 
reduced oxygenation in CVST may trigger SIADH as 
a result of the systemic response. Further, a blood clot 
in the venous sinuses can lead to localized brain injury 
and cerebral edema, thereby releasing ADH [10]. Inter estingly, there are only few cases in the existing litera ture that report venous sinus thrombosis complicated 
with SIADH. Afaf Albalawi reported a case of CVST and 
hyponatraemia associated citalopram use for behavioral 
symptoms in a patient with Parkinson’s disease. In this 
case hyponatremia was thought to be due to SIADH from 
citalopram use and from CVST [11].
Considering the serious nature of both CVST and 
SIADH, a multidisciplinary approach involving hematol ogy, neurology, and neurosurgery is important for opti mal management. Furthermore, it is important to rule 
out other causes of CVST, such as thrombotic disorders, 
infection, and malignancy before confirming the diagno sis of traumatic CVST.
Conclusion
Even though traumatic head injuries are a not a common 
cause of CVSTs, our case highlights the importance of 
considering CVST as a differential diagnosis in patients 
presenting with head injury. Because the clinical indica tors of post-traumatic cerebral venous sinus thrombosis 
CVST are nonspecific and may resemble symptoms of 
severe traumatic brain injury, it is frequently underdiag nosed. Diagnosis of CVST can be challenging, and neu roimaging plays an important role. Early identification 
and aggressive treatment are essential to reduce mor bidity and mortality. Anticoagulation and endovascular 
therapies remain the mainstay of treatment for post-trau matic CVST.
